positive.review:
As I write this review, the next title (EU5) is slated to release tomorrow and I felt compelled to write a review and pay homage to the greatest strategy game of all time before I must say goodbye. 

This game is so much more than just a map painter, it's a an escape to a different world, a glimpse from a time long gone, a strategy sandbox where you can write history in so many different ways. For many of us, the year 1444 has become as familiar as our own birthdays, the borders and rulers of that frozen moment etched into memory like a second language. This game has taught me more about history and geography than any college class or textbook ever could. 

There‚Äôs such a simple joy in choosing a nation and immersing yourself in its story, roleplaying its triumphs and disasters, navigating diplomacy, warfare, and economics in a living, reactive world. 

Sure, it has a significant learning curve, but it incorporates the best systems and ideas about economics, warfare, and diplomacy from similar games into one massive sandbox. Even after 4000+ hours, every campaign is different, a unique story told through the lens of ambition, power, and chance.  A single decision can ripple through centuries. Truly a game with a unlimited replayability. 

The multiplayer is another aspect entirely. I could write pages more on that, but to keep brief, they were the fondest gaming memories I'll have. 

No other game has continued to captivate me 10 years later.

It's truly a masterpiece in its genre. 

10/10

This was the first computer game I ever owned for myself, let alone the first game I ever got on Steam. 

I just graduated high school when I first got this game in 2013 and I can't describe what essence drew me to this game. I didn't know it yet but I had discovered I love this game genre, Grand Strategy. From then on I would play this game whenever I had the chance. From my first run as a Brandenburg attempt, to my more serious runs as the Ottomans, to the achievements hunting runs I do now, I adore this game.

The controls are simple enough that a young person can take it up easily. It makes you think and strategize every time, even though you know certain events are coming up. It is always a unique game every time and even with the release of its successor, I would likely find myself still coming to this game. I say all this as I migrate this game over to a $4k Linux build.

I will always treasure EU4 for getting me into the world of not just steam and PC gaming, but computers in general. I only wish I could get my hands on a physical copy as a piece of memorabilia.

Words alone are not enough to describe what this game has meant to the community. Life long friendships have come out of this game. I have a feeling that many future statesman, generals, and world leader will have grown up playing this game. I just want to thank the developers and more importantly the EU4/ EU5 community for making this series so enjoyable. I have played EU5 and I truly think it is the most advanced historical strategy game yet. With the integration of Populations and the great thematic elements of that time period in the rise of the Bourgeoisie and the centralization of power. These two things are what lead to the enlightenment, the industrial revolution and the modern world in which we live today. EU4 began this journey and I truly think EU5 has the potential to be the most in depth game ever created thus far.

The ultimate grand strategy experience, at least until the fifth installment is a little more mature, so it's still a good bet for scratching that itch.

It's not just a map painter, but one of the few that manages to combine economic, military, diplomatic, and cultural management without being a mess. It can be a little overwhelming at first, but you can always pick a relatively easy country to get the hang of it, the only downside is that this game has been a constantly evolving project for many years, which means you need to buy several DLCs to experience the game in its entirety.
EU4 is hard to learn at first, but once it clicks, hours disappear without you noticing and becomes very fun üòä. Top 5 games definitely.

I wish I could rate this 1-5 instead of a plain yes or no.  It is a yes, but barely.  For a 4x game it is fairly good, but it lacks a quality late game.  One of the things that separates paradox grand strategy from traditional 4x games is the ability to create new challenged as the game goes on so the end game is just as engaging as the early game.  Most people don't play past 150 years with any given playthrough and the reasons are obvious, the late game is boring and unfulfilling.
Another issue I have is that this game more than any other paradox title attempts to disguise obscurity as complexity.  The game is marketed as deep and complex, but in truth the mechanics are not all the complicated, they are simply hidden in multiple nested sub menus and obscure decisions.  Once you learn where everything is hidden the supposed complexity is reduced to nothing more than a standard recruit, conquer, consolidate loop.
Over all it was fun, but I put over 1000 hours into crusader kings and stellaris even more.  This game I played for two months and never plan to play again.

EU4 is an RNG based grand strategy sandbox game from 2013 that allows you to play as any country from every continent (except Antarctica) from 1444-1821. Your goal is to become the most powerful nation on Earth by conquering as much as you can before 1821. You have three types of powers that you spend on a multitude of things to strengthen your country, administrative, diplomatic, and military power. Admin is spent primarily on stability and administrative tech, diplo is spent on reducing war exhaustion, admirals, and diplomatic tech, and military is spent on generals and military tech.

Every country has one currency called ducats. Ducats can be attained from subsidies from other countries, through base trade, base tax, base production, war reparations in peace deals, and through demanding ducats in peace deals. Ducats are extremely important for buying a lot of things and if you run out of ducats and take too many loans you can go into bankruptcy for 10 years which plunges your country into -3 stability, wipes out all three powers to leave you at -100 for each one, gives your armies and navies -50% morale (basically hp modifier), and wipes out all of your loans. Bankruptcy is one of the worst things that can happen in EU4 besides stackwipes (your entire army getting destroyed after one battle) but is usually easily avoidable if you're skilled/experienced at the game. 

I could go on about all the mechanics but I just wanted to go over the big basic core parts of the game. The ONLY negative is the ridiculous amount of DLCs over the span of 12 years, much of it having a big impact on core mechanics of the game like developing provinces. 

Overall this game deserves a 9.5/10, if on sale I highly recommend buying and paying the monthly subscription to see if you want to buy any of the DLCs or not.

negative.review: Let me get this straight, if i want Art of War I now have to rebuy the game because its considered so neccessary its included in the game now, but not the version i bought years ago.  This company hates its long time customers.

Like all paradox games, they made it better from release and then made it worse over time by adding more short-sighted updates, unnecessary content, and untested mechanics to milk more money out of the game. Features and AI that once worked well become overburdened and broken as Paradox doesn't play test how new features focusing on new areas cooperate with old features.

Fixed trade routes are the most idiotic thing I've ever seen in a grand strategy game like this.. The trade flows only in one predefined direction and the directions CANNOT be changed.. 

Let's say you are playing as Australia and you develop your country a LOT. But you still can't make any money in Australia because the only trade route present leaves Australia to Europe. ALL trade routes move from rest of the world to Europe (which is historically accurate but the whole point of playing such a game is to be able to rewrite the history by making different choices)

And money is the main limiting factor in this game if you're not in Europe which has all the end trade nodes. You can't have a large standing army outside Europe/India because you're broke af always...

When I first started Europa Universalis IV, I realized this is one of the most complicated games I‚Äôve ever played ‚Äî period. The number of buttons, menus, and systems thrown at you from the start is overwhelming. Managing everything feels like trying to play on ten different chess boards at once, each with its own rules and objectives.

That said, the level of detail in this game is absolutely incredible. Every province, nation, and historical event feels handcrafted, and once you understand what‚Äôs going on, it‚Äôs actually very rewarding. The balance between nations and mechanics is surprisingly well done for a game of this scope.

Unfortunately, Paradox‚Äôs DLC model ruins what could have been one of the greatest strategy games ever made. Half of what should be the full experience is locked behind dozens of paid expansions, most costing over $20 each. To get the ‚Äúcomplete‚Äù version of this game, you‚Äôd have to spend a few hundred dollars, which is absurd and unfair to players and consumers.

Overall, Europa Universalis IV is a deep, fascinating grand strategy experience buried under one of the most predatory DLC systems in gaming. Enjoy it if you can, but do not buy Europa Universalis V unless Paradox changes its practices.

Fixed trade routes are the most idiotic thing I've ever seen in a grand strategy game like this.. The trade flows only in one predefined direction and the directions CANNOT be changed.. 

Let's say you are playing as Australia and you develop your country a LOT. But you still can't make any money in Australia because the only trade route present leaves Australia to Europe. ALL trade routes move from rest of the world to Europe (which is historically accurate but the whole point of playing such a game is to be able to rewrite the history by making different choices)

And money is the main limiting factor in this game if you're not in Europe which has all the end trade nodes. You can't have a large standing army outside Europe/India because you're broke af always...

When I first started Europa Universalis IV, I realized this is one of the most complicated games I‚Äôve ever played ‚Äî period. The number of buttons, menus, and systems thrown at you from the start is overwhelming. Managing everything feels like trying to play on ten different chess boards at once, each with its own rules and objectives.

That said, the level of detail in this game is absolutely incredible. Every province, nation, and historical event feels handcrafted, and once you understand what‚Äôs going on, it‚Äôs actually very rewarding. The balance between nations and mechanics is surprisingly well done for a game of this scope.

Unfortunately, Paradox‚Äôs DLC model ruins what could have been one of the greatest strategy games ever made. Half of what should be the full experience is locked behind dozens of paid expansions, most costing over $20 each. To get the ‚Äúcomplete‚Äù version of this game, you‚Äôd have to spend a few hundred dollars, which is absurd and unfair to players and consumers.

Overall, Europa Universalis IV is a deep, fascinating grand strategy experience buried under one of the most predatory DLC systems in gaming. Enjoy it if you can, but do not buy Europa Universalis V unless Paradox changes its practices.
